results.headline: What’s the 411 on Those Witch Guys?

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Covenant

results.summary_short: The director Renny Harlin proves that “Exorcist: The Beginning” was not the nadir of his career with this thriller about boy witches fending off a nefarious transfer student.

results.headline: Deep Pockets in Iraq
results.display_title: Iraq for Sale: The War Profiteers

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Iraq for Sale: The War Profiteers

results.summary_short: A febrile blend of facts, liberal outrage and emotional manipulation, Robert Greenwald’s documentary examines the role of private contractors in Iraq.

results.headline: Sisyphus, Making It Work on the Streets of New York

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Man Push Cart

results.summary_short: Ramin Bahrani’s bare-bones film concerns the daily grind of a Pakistani immigrant who sells coffee, doughnuts and bagels on the streets of New York City.

results.headline: Struggling Rock Band With Megawatt Manager
results.display_title: I Trust You to Kill Me

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of I Trust You to Kill Me

results.summary_short: That Rocco DeLuca and the Burden are attached to Kiefer Sutherland is the only discernible reason for the existence of Manu Boyer’s inconsequential documentary.

results.headline: Mother Needing Her Child, Trying Not to Need Heroin

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sherrybaby

results.summary_short: What distinguishes "Sherrybaby" from its many peers is the quality of the writing and the precision of Maggie Gyllenhaal’s performance.

results.headline: Road Trip With Family, Latin Version

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Rolling Family

results.summary_short: Don’t fret if you find it frustrating to unscramble the blood ties or follow the fragmented domestic dramas that jostle one another in Pablo Trapero’s big-hearted ensemble comedy.

results.headline: Going Down Under to Save a Sacred Baby Elephant

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Protector

results.summary_short: A provincial Thai warrior rampages through Australia busting skulls and shouting “You stole my elephants!” in this infectious b-movie smack down.

results.headline: A Cop Confronts Some Hard Cases, Including His Own Boss

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Young Lieutenant

results.summary_short: This tough, satisfying French film is an austere crime drama of the sort that rarely makes it to American screens except on cable television.

results.headline: The Quiet Desperation of Superman

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hollywoodland

results.summary_short: The movies love a tasty murder, which is why Ben Affleck has packed on the pounds, slipped on some tights and given this exasperating film far more than it gives in return.

results.headline: Cultural and Generational Clashes, Played Out for Laughs in the Suburbs

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Red Doors

results.summary_short: This agreeable, lightweight movie turns the malaises of a suburban Chinese-American family into bittersweet farce that teeters between cheeky humor and surface pathos.

results.headline: The Gentle Life of a Priest, Made Famous in Death

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Saint of 9/11

results.summary_short: “Saint of 9/11” is a touching elegy for the Rev. Mychal Judge, the much-loved New York City Fire Department chaplain who died at the World Trade Center.

results.headline: In Search of a Better Life, and a Place to Be Accepted

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Paper Dolls

results.summary_short: This modest documentary examines the lives of a group of transsexual Philippine immigrants who work as home attendants for elderly Israelis and also perform in Tel Aviv nightclubs.

results.headline: When Cantors Were Stars, Just Like the Ballplayers

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Cantor's Tale

results.summary_short: Erik Greenberg Anjou’s charming documentary about the cantor Jacob Mendelson is more concerned with singing praises than arguing over orthodoxies.

results.headline: Learning All About the Girls and the Bees

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Wicker Man

results.summary_short: “The Wicker Man” is comically inept as a horror movie, unable to even manage an effective false scare, or sustain suspense for more than a beat or two.

results.headline: Gore, Gimmicks and a Hero With a Literal Rage to Live

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Crank

results.summary_short: Jason Stratham rampages through Los Angeles in this retread of “Speed,” but for a movie premised on unrelenting action, “Crank” proves fatally turgid.

results.headline: A Portrait of the Artist as a Visionary, a Voyeur and a Brand-Name Star

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Andy Warhol: A Documentary Film

results.summary_short: Ric Burns’s absorbing four-hour critical biography of the seminal pop artist is devoted to the proposition that Warhol was the greatest artist of the second half of the 20th century.

results.headline: Some Material May Be Inappropriate or Mystifying, and the Rating May Be as Well
results.display_title: This Film is Not Yet Rated

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of This Film is Not Yet Rated

results.summary_short: Kirby Dick's feisty, intellectually engaging documentary tries to illuminate an aspect of moviemaking — and moviegoing — that is deliberately left in the dark.

results.headline: When ‘In Search Of’ Is Not a Phrase in the Ads

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mutual Appreciation

results.summary_short: Written and directed by Andrew Bujalski, this wonderful independent film won’t save or change your life, but it may make your heart swell. Its aim is modest and true.

results.headline: The Noblest Collie of All Bounds Anew in the Glen

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Lassie

results.summary_short: Everything old is new again in the latest film about the beloved pooch with the I.Q. of a grad student and the instincts of a boomerang.

results.headline: Searching China, Heart on Sleeve
results.display_title: Riding Alone for Thousands of Miles

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Riding Alone for Thousands of Miles

results.summary_short: Zhang Yimou takes a pause between marital arts extravaganzas with this simple, affecting melodrama about a mournful Japanese patriarch on an odyssey through rural China.
